content:
I installed Ubuntu in Windows WSL and installed the following in Ubuntu: https://leanprover-community.github.io/install/debian.html

How can I start Lean or VSCode in Ubuntu? \usr\bin\code gives: "No such file or directory".
Start VSCode from the host. There's an official WSL extension for using toolchains and installing extensions in the guest.

Now I found: The WSL extension in VSCode works fine if I installed a Linux (Ubuntu) with WSL before.
But now I have to install elan in this WSL-Ubuntu environment:
The command curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/leanprover/elan/master/elan-init.sh -sSf | sh gives the error: curl: (6) Could not resolve host: raw.githubusercontent.com.
Does this internet address exist?
It most certainly does -- are you behind a firewall perhaps?

Yes, clearly. Who not?
Windows Firewall and antivirus software. That's no problem in Windows. The other packages were downloaded and installed without problems.

I clicked on VSCodes's WSL icon "Install Lean Version Manager":
bash -c 'curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/leanprover/elan/master/elan-init.sh -sSf | sh -s -- -y --default-toolchain leanprover/lean4:stable || ich@DESKTOP-8KEP48L:~$ bash -c 'curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/leanprover/elan/master/elan-init.sh -sSf | sh -s -- -y --default-toolchain leanprover/lean4:stable || (echo && read -n 1 -s -r -p "Install failed, press ENTER to continue...")' && exit

the output:

curl --version
curl 8.5.0 (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu) libcurl/8.5.0 OpenSSL/3.0.13 zlib/1.3 brotli/1.1.0 zstd/1.5.5 libidn2/2.3.7 libpsl/0.21.2 (+libidn2/2.3.7) libssh/0.10.6/openssl/zlib nghttp2/1.59.0 librtmp/2.3 OpenLDAP/2.6.7
Release-Date: 2023-12-06, security patched: 8.5.0-2ubuntu10.4
Does it work if you disable the firewall?

I didn't want to believe it: I had to disable my firewall, Lean installed now. That's horrible!
Many many thanks to all of you.
Justus Willbad has marked this topic as resolved.

I didn't want to believe it: I had to disable my firewall, Lean installed now. That's horrible!

Your firewall is being overly restrictive, that domain is the domain for essentially all raw content hosted by GitHub. Disabling it confirms it was the issue -- but doesn't explain why or how it's misconfigured. If you were interested, you could investigate why or how to fix your firewall, but as far as the Lean install is concerned if it works now, great.
